badmephisto.comment:
The
algorithm has a little bit of a symmetry to it. I have a very weird way
to memorize this algorithm tracking the two corners in UBR and UFR
around the cube as I do it. But I know that many of my friends do it
differently. Find what suits you best, it is not too hard or long.

logiqx.description: A9 [commutator] / [conjugate] - [x R2: [R U R', D2]]
Modified Jb-Perm potentially good for big cubes

cases.description:
Clearly an A-Perm thanks to the checkerboard pattern (4 facelets) and the 2-Bar outer.

Easily recognizable as Aa-Perm because the checkerboard pattern is on the left and the 2-Bar outer on the right.

feature.description:
Headlights accompanied by a 2-Bar outer can only be an A-Perm or G-Perm.

The presence of a checkerboard pattern (4 facelets) is considered to differentiate cases.

A-Perms = 3 colors, G-Perms = 4 colors.
feature.name: Headlights + 2-Bar (Outer)

cases.observation: Checkerboard pattern on the left (4 facelets)

cases.description:
Clearly an A-Perm because of the 2x2 block at the front and the opposite corner facelet.

Easily recognizable as Ab-Perm because the opposite corner facelet is on the right.

feature.description:
Symmetrical 2-bars and 2x2 blocks can only be a Y-Perm, A-Perm or V-Perm.

The outer corners are considered to differentiate cases. The Y-Perm and V-Perm are most distinctive.

A-Perms = 3 colors, Y-Perm / V-Perm = 4 colors.
feature.name: Double 2-Bar (Symmetric)

cases.observation: Right corner is the opposite of the block

cases.description:
Definitely an adjacent corner swap because the outermost corner facelets are identical.

Recognizable as Aa-Perm because of the 2-bar at the back-left and the opposite facelets at the front-right.

feature.description:
2-Bar outers connected to an opposite corner can only be a V-Perm, G-Perm or A-Perm.

The side adjacent to the 2-bar is considered to differentiate cases.

G-Perms = 3 colors, V-Perms / A-Perms = 4 colors.
feature.name: 2-Bar outer (Opposite Corner)

cases.observation: Opposite facelets at the front-right

cases.description:
Clearly an A-Perm because the facelet between the headlights is the opposite of a checkerboard pattern (5 facelets).

Easily recognizable as Aa-Perm because the "almost" checkerboard pattern is on the right.

The edge on the left is also the opposite of the rear corner.

feature.description:
Headlights containing an adjacent edge can only be a R-Perm, G-Perm or A-Perm.

The presence of a checkerboard pattern (4 or 5 facelets) is considered to differentiate cases.

R-Perms = 3 colors, A-Perms / G-Perms = 4 colors.
feature.name: Headlights (Adjacent Edge)

cases.observation: Almost checkerboard pattern on the right (5 facelets)

badmephisto.comment:
This
is the exact same type of motion you do in A(a). If you memorized it by
motions instead of notation, you should be able to do this one without
too many problems.

description: Symmetric version with M, S and mirror of Aa.

logiqx.description: A9 [commutator] / [conjugate] - [x R2: [D2, R U R']]

name: PLL Ab

cases.description:
Clearly an A-Perm because the facelet between the headlights is the opposite of a checkerboard pattern (5 facelets).

Easily recognizable as Ab-Perm because the "almost" checkerboard pattern is on the left.

The edge on the right is also the opposite of the rear corner.

feature.description:
Headlights containing an adjacent edge can only be a R-Perm, G-Perm or A-Perm.

The presence of a checkerboard pattern (4 or 5 facelets) is considered to differentiate cases.

R-Perms = 3 colors, A-Perms / G-Perms = 4 colors.

Recognizable as Ab-Perm because of the 2-bar at the back-right and the opposite facelets at the front-left.

2-Bar outers connected to an opposite corner can only be a V-Perm, G-Perm or A-Perm.

The side adjacent to the 2-bar is considered to differentiate cases.

G-Perms = 3 colors, V-Perms / A-Perms = 4 colors.
feature.name: 2-Bar outer (Opposite Corner)

cases.observation: Opposite facelets at the front-left

Clearly an A-Perm because of the 2x2 block at the front and the opposite corner facelet.

Easily recognizable as Ab-Perm because the opposite corner facelet is on the left.

The outer corners are considered to differentiate cases. The Y-Perm and V-Perm are most distinctive.

badmephisto.comment: This algorithm has a nice symmetry to it, as highlighted. Some people find the second one faster to execute

description: Symmetry with the U' at the start and end, and the D that goes back and forth each turn.

logiqx.description: [Commutator] combination - [R U' R', D] [R, U R' D]

variations.description: Execution starts with a wide turn
Execution ends with a wide turn

logiqx.description: Long algorithm but decent for [OH] and big cubes
Long algorithm but decent for [OH] and big cubes

name: PLL E

cases.description:
Definitely a diagonal corner swap because the outermost corner facelets are adjacent colors.

Recognizable as E-Perm because of the "malformed" pair in the front-left, resulting in a partial checkerboard pattern (3 facelets).

The E-Perm has two appearances and looks the same after a U2.

feature.description:
The miscellaneous cases without matching bookends can only be an E-Perm, V-Perm or Y-Perm.

The checkerboard pattern in the V-Perm (malformed 2x2 block) distinguishes it from the E-Perm (malformed pair) and Y-Perm.

E-Perm / V-Perm / Y-Perm = 4 colors.
feature.name: Miscellaneous without Bookends

cases.notes: Learn the features of E, Y and V
cases.observation: Malformed pair at front-left

cases.description:
Definitely a diagonal corner swap because the outermost corner facelets are adjacent colors.

Recognizable as E-Perm because of the "malformed" pair in the front-right, resulting in a partial checkerboard pattern (3 facelets).

The E-Perm has two appearances and looks the same after a U2.

feature.description:
The miscellaneous cases without matching bookends can only be an E-Perm, V-Perm or Y-Perm.

The checkerboard pattern in the V-Perm (malformed 2x2 block) distinguishes it from the E-Perm (malformed pair) and Y-Perm.

E-Perm / V-Perm / Y-Perm = 4 colors.
feature.name: Miscellaneous without Bookends

cases.notes: Learn the features of E, Y and V
cases.observation: Malformed pair at front-right

badmephisto.comment:
If
      you know V permutation, this one is REALLY easy. I highlighted the
      differences. There is simply one extra U, so instead of R' U R' in the
      beginning you have R' U U R' (or R' U2 R'), and then you have to undo
      that U at the end of the algorithm, so there is an extra U' that pops
      in from nowhere near the end of the algorithm.

description: Resembles Jb-Perm and T-Perm except the end.

logiqx.description: [Conjugate] of T-Perm - [R' U' F': T-Perm]
Playing with [F2L] pairs - track FR + BR + FL

variations.description: Note the [COLL] algorithm in the middle - case F2

logiqx.description: [RUL] algorithm

name: PLL F

cases.description:
Clearly a F-Perm because of the lonesome 3-bar.

It is also worth knowing that the edge on the right is the opposite of the front corner.

feature.description:
The 3-bar without headlights can only be a J-Perm or F-Perm.

The presence and location of a 2-bar is considered to differentiate cases.

J-Perms = 3 colors, F-Perm = 4 colors.
feature.name: 3-Bar without Headlights

cases.observation: Right edge is the opposite of front corner

cases.description:
Definitely an adjacent corner swap because the outermost corner facelets are identical.

Recognizable as F-Perm because of the "malformed" 2x2 block at the front, resulting in a checkerboard pattern (4 facelets).

feature.description:
The miscellaneous cases with matching bookends can only be a F-Perm, R-Perm or G-Perm.

The checkerboard pattern in the F-Perm (malformed 2x2 block) distinguishes it from the R-Perms and G-Perms (malformed pairs).

F-Perm = 3 colors, R-Perms / G-Perms = 4 colors.
feature.name: Miscellaneous with Bookends

cases.observation: Malformed 2x2 block (checkerboard pattern)

cases.description:
Definitely an adjacent corner swap because the outermost corner facelets are identical.

Recognizable as F-Perm because of the "malformed" 2x2 block at the front, resulting in a checkerboard pattern (4 facelets).

feature.description:
The miscellaneous cases with matching bookends can only be a F-Perm, R-Perm or G-Perm.

The checkerboard pattern in the F-Perm (malformed 2x2 block) distinguishes it from the R-Perms and G-Perms (malformed pairs).

F-Perm = 3 colors, R-Perms / G-Perms = 4 colors.
feature.name: Miscellaneous with Bookends

cases.observation: Malformed 2x2 block (checkerboard pattern)

cases.description:
Clearly a F-Perm because of the lonesome 3-bar.

It is also worth knowing that the edge on the left is the opposite of the front corner.

feature.description:
The 3-bar without headlights can only be a J-Perm or F-Perm.

The presence and location of a 2-bar is considered to differentiate cases.

J-Perms = 3 colors, F-Perm = 4 colors.

cases.observation: Left edge is the opposite of front corner

badmephisto.comment: This is very similar to G(c). Everything just goes the other way :)

logiqx.description: Standard algorithm

cases.description:
Clearly a Ga-Perm / Gc-Perm because the facelet between the headlights is the opposite of a checkerboard pattern (4 facelets).

Easily recognizable as Ga-Perm because the "almost" checkerboard pattern is on the left and the 2-Bar outer on the right.

feature.description:
Headlights accompanied by a 2-Bar outer can only be an A-Perm or G-Perm.

The presence of a checkerboard pattern (4 facelets) is considered to differentiate cases.

A-Perms = 3 colors, G-Perms = 4 colors.
feature.name: Headlights + 2-Bar (Outer)

cases.observation: Almost checkerboard pattern on the left (4 facelets)

cases.description:
Definitely an adjacent corner swap because the outermost corner facelets are identical.

Recognizable as Ga-Perm because of the 2-bar at the front-left and the edge on the right being an adjacent of the back-left corner.

feature.description:
Inside 2-bars can only be a G-Perm or Y-Perm.

The edge adjacent to the 2-bar is considered to differentiate cases.

G-Perms / Y-Perm = 4 colors.
feature.name: Inside 2-Bar

cases.observation: Edge on the right is an adjacent of the back-left corner

cases.description:
Definitely an adjacent corner swap because the outermost corner facelets are identical.

Recognizable as Ga-Perm because the edge on the left is the opposite of the front-right corner and the edge on the right matches the front-left corner.

You might find the "malformed" pair at the front-right is useful during recognition.

feature.description:
The miscellaneous cases with matching bookends can only be a F-Perm, R-Perm or G-Perm.

The checkerboard pattern in the F-Perm (malformed 2x2 block) distinguishes it from the R-Perms and G-Perms (malformed pairs).

F-Perm = 3 colors, R-Perms / G-Perms = 4 colors.
feature.name: Miscellaneous with Bookends

cases.observation: Almost malformed 2x2 block

cases.description:
Clearly a Ga-Perm / Gc-Perm because of the checkerboard pattern (4 facelets) and the absence of a 2-Bar outer.

Easily recognizable as Ga-Perm because the checkerboard pattern is on the right.

The edge on the left is also the opposite of the front corner.

feature.description:
Headlights containing an adjacent edge can only be a R-Perm, G-Perm or A-Perm.

The presence of a checkerboard pattern (4 or 5 facelets) is considered to differentiate cases.

R-Perms = 3 colors, A-Perms / G-Perms = 4 colors.
feature.name: Headlights (Adjacent Edge)

cases.observation: Checkerboard pattern on the right (4 facelets)

badmephisto.comment:
This
is similar. First take out the pair that is right under the aligned
2x1x1 block, as in G(d), and then rotate the cube, and do a similar
pattern. See how there is a symmetry to the U's again? u U U' u'. When
I execute, I do the first R2 as R' R', counterclockwise motion. So I
think CCW, CCW, CW, CW, and final R2 just to fix it all up.

logiqx.description: Standard algorithm

cases.description:
Clearly a Gb-Perm / Gd-Perm because the headlights contain the opposite edge color.

Recognizable as Gb-Perm because the headlights are on the left and the adjacent edge is the opposite of the front corner.

feature.description:
Headlights containing an opposite edge can only be a G-Perm.

The edge adjacent to the headlights is considered to differentiate cases.

G-Perms = 3 or 4 colors.
feature.name: Headlights (Opposite Edge)

cases.observation: Right edge is the opposite of front corner

Definitely an adjacent corner swap because the outermost corner facelets are identical.

Recognizable as Gb-Perm because of the 2-bar at the back-right and the opposite facelets at the back-left.

You might find the "malformed" pair at the front-left is useful during recognition.

The side adjacent to the 2-bar is considered to differentiate cases.

G-Perms = 3 colors, V-Perms / A-Perms = 4 colors.

You might find the corner on the left useful during recognition.

The edge adjacent to the 2-bar is considered to differentiate cases.

G-Perms / Y-Perm = 4 colors.

cases.description:
Clearly a Gb-Perm / Gd-Perm because the headlights contain the opposite edge color.

Recognizable as Gb-Perm because the edge on the left matches the headlights.

The edge on the left is also the opposite of the back corner.

feature.description:
Headlights containing an opposite edge can only be a G-Perm.

The edge adjacent to the headlights is considered to differentiate cases.

G-Perms = 3 or 4 colors.

cases.observation: Left edge matches right headlights

badmephisto.comment:
This
is simply G(d) inverted. But I find it useless to remember it like
that. This is like a completely new algorithm for me. Note the still
distinct pattern to the U's. And also R's. Remember it as you wish. The
last part yRU'R' just inserts an F2L pair once the first part is done.

logiqx.description: [RUF] algorithm. Requires decent [TPS] to be fast
Standard algorithm

Clearly a Ga-Perm / Gc-Perm because of the checkerboard pattern (4 facelets) and the absence of a 2-Bar outer.

Easily recognizable as Gc-Perm because the checkerboard pattern is on the left.

The edge on the right is also the opposite of the front corner.

Definitely an adjacent corner swap because the outermost corner facelets are identical.

Recognizable as Gc-Perm because the edge on the right is the opposite of the front-left corner and the edge on the left matches the front-right corner.

You might find the "malformed" pair at the front-left is useful during recognition.

The miscellaneous cases with matching bookends can only be a F-Perm, R-Perm or G-Perm.

Definitely an adjacent corner swap because the outermost corner facelets are identical.

Recognizable as Gc-Perm because of the 2-bar at the front-right and the edge on the left being an adjacent of the back-right corner.

The edge adjacent to the 2-bar is considered to differentiate cases.

cases.description:
Clearly a Ga-Perm / Gc-Perm because the facelet between the headlights is the opposite of a checkerboard pattern (4 facelets).

Easily recognizable as Gc-Perm because the "almost" checkerboard pattern is on the right and the 2-Bar outer on the left.

feature.description:
Headlights accompanied by a 2-Bar outer can only be an A-Perm or G-Perm.

The presence of a checkerboard pattern (4 facelets) is considered to differentiate cases.

A-Perms = 3 colors, G-Perms = 4 colors.
feature.name: Headlights + 2-Bar (Outer)

cases.observation: Almost checkerboard pattern on the right (4 facelets)

badmephisto.comment:
RUR'
takes out a pair. Then rotate the cube, and now the fun part starts. I
highleted the R rotations so that you can see the pattern better.
Notice in particular how the U turns are. It is u' U' U u. It has a
very nice symmetry to it. The R's I remember as follows: Since in
execution I perfrom the R2 as RR (in clockwise motion), I see them as R
clockwise twice, and then R counterclockwise twice, and the final R2 is
just to finish up the algorithm. You are welcome to come up with better
memory techniques for this things. I know a couple of friends, each
with different ways of remembering these G perms...

logiqx.description: [RUF] algorithm. Requires decent [TPS] to be fast
Standard algorithm

The edge on the right is also the opposite of the back corner.

Recognizable as Gd-Perm because the headlights are on the right and the adjacent edge is the opposite of the front corner.

The edge adjacent to the headlights is considered to differentiate cases.

badmephisto.comment: A very easy to remember algorithm. Note how the M2's always alternate, and in between you simply have just U, U2, U

description: U, U2, U always surrounded by M2.

logiqx.description: [MU] [commutator] / [conjugate] - [M2 U': [M2, U2]]
Note the Ortega / Varasano [OLL] algorithm (H case)

name: PLL H

cases.description:
Clearly an [EPLL] because of the headlights on both sides.

Easily recognizable as H-Perm because both sets of headlights contain the opposite edge color.

H-perm looks the same from all four possible angles.

feature.description:
Double headlights with at least one opposite edge can only be a H-Perm or U-Perm.

The two edges are considered to differentiate cases. The H-Perm is the most distinct.

U-Perms = 3 colors, H-Perm = 4 colors.
feature.name: Double Lights (Opposite Edge)

cases.observation: Both headlights contain the opposite edge

badmephisto.comment:
1st
      part is exactly as in N(b), below. But then you do U2RU'R'U2 which I
      find personally very easy to remember. The last part (RLU)just simply
      restores all yellows and I find it very easy to see it visually.

logiqx.description: Playing with [F2L] pairs - track BR + FL. Similar to Na
[COLL] combination - [RBAS], [RBN]

cases.description:
Clearly a J-Perm because of the 3-bar and inside 2-bar which look like a 3x2 block.

Easily recognizable as Ja-Perm because the 3-bar is on the left and the inside 2-bar on the right.

feature.description:
The 3-bar without headlights can only be a J-Perm or F-Perm.

The presence and location of a 2-bar is considered to differentiate cases.

J-Perms = 3 colors, F-Perm = 4 colors.
feature.name: 3-Bar without Headlights

cases.observation: Inside 2-bar on the right

cases.description:
Clearly a J-Perm because of the inside and 2-Bar outers, one of which is connected to an opposite corner.

Easily recognizable as Ja-Perm because the 2-bars are on the left.

feature.description:
Asymmetrical 2-bars can only be a J-Perm or N-Perm.

The relationships of the corner facelets are considered to differentiate cases.

J-Perms = 3 colors, N-Perms = 4 colors.
feature.name: Double 2-Bar (Asymmetrical)

cases.observation: Opposite corner facelet on the right

cases.description:
Clearly a J-Perm because of the inside and 2-Bar outers, one of which is connected to an opposite corner.

Easily recognizable as Ja-Perm because the 2-bars are on the left.

feature.description:
Asymmetrical 2-bars can only be a J-Perm or N-Perm.

The relationships of the corner facelets are considered to differentiate cases.

J-Perms = 3 colors, N-Perms = 4 colors.
feature.name: Double 2-Bar (Asymmetrical)

cases.observation: Opposite corner facelet on the front-left

cases.description:
Clearly a J-Perm because of the 3-bar and the 2-Bar outer, separated by an adjacent corner facelet.

Easily recognizable as Ja-Perm because the 2-Bar outer is on the left, disconnected from the 3-bar on the right.

feature.description:
The 3-bar without headlights can only be a J-Perm or F-Perm.

The presence and location of a 2-bar is considered to differentiate cases.

J-Perms = 3 colors, F-Perm = 4 colors.
feature.name: 3-Bar without Headlights

cases.observation: 2-Bar outer on the left

badmephisto.comment:
Notice
that this is EXACTLY the same algorithm as the one above but the RUR'F'
from the end was now moved to the beginning! So just do RUR'F' and then
start doing the T permutation (above) until you see that the cube is
solved!

description: Like T-Perm, but the start is the end.

logiqx.description: [Conjugate] of T-Perm - [R U R' F': T-Perm]
[COLL] combination - [RFAS], [RFN]

badmephisto.comment:
Note how the algorithm is made up of two IDENTICAL pieces (in squiggly brackets).
      To memorize this, track the corner in UBR. As you do R'UL', it will
      travel along a U on the top layer of the cube. Then do U2, and then
      restore yellows by doing RU'L. Then repeat that whole thing again. 
      I hate executing this algorithm. It's a good thing that it rarely ever comes up.

logiqx.description: Playing with [F2L] pair - track BR corner
Playing with [F2L] pairs - track BR + FL

cases.description:
Definitely a diagonal corner swap because the outermost corner facelets are adjacent colors.

Easily recognizable as Nb-Perm because of the 2-bars on the left and opposite corner colors.

Nb-perm looks the same from all four possible angles.

feature.description:
Asymmetrical 2-bars can only be a J-Perm or N-Perm.

The relationships of the corner facelets are considered to differentiate cases.

J-Perms = 3 colors, N-Perms = 4 colors.
feature.name: Double 2-Bar (Asymmetrical)

cases.observation: Opposite corner facelet on the front-left and back-right

badmephisto.comment:
This
is just the reflection of the above. You need to do the above, but
using the left hand instead of the right hand. You will be able to
mirror the R permutation to your left hand after about a weeks practice
of doing it with your right hand. When it becomes a little bit of
muscle memory for you it should be really easy to mirror the algorithm
with the left hand. So if you can't do it right away, just wait a
little more and get a little more comfortable with R(b). The second algorithm is an alternative that I sometime like to do because it involves the (faster) right hand instead.

logiqx.description: [RUF] algorithm. Decent for big cubes.
Contains an 8-move [commutator] - [U, R D R']

cases.description:
Clearly a R-Perm because the headlights contain an adjacent edge color.

Easily recognizable as Ra-Perm because the headlights are on the left and inside 2-bar on the right.

feature.description:
Headlights accompanied by an inside 2-bar can only be a T-Perm or R-Perm.

The edge between the headlights is considered to differentiate cases.

T-Perm = 3 colors, R-Perms = 4 colors.
feature.name: Headlights + 2-Bar (Inside)

cases.observation: Headlights contain an adjacent edge

cases.description:
Definitely an adjacent corner swap because the outermost corner facelets are identical.

Recognizable as Ra-Perm because of the 2-bar at the back-left and the edge on the right matching the front-left corner.

You might find the "malformed" pair at the front-right is useful during recognition.

feature.description:
2-Bar outers connected to an adjacent corner can only be a R-Perm or T-Perm.

The edge adjacent to the 2-bar is considered to differentiate cases.

R-Perms = 3 colors, T-Perm = 4 colors.
feature.name: 2-Bar outer (Corner Adjacent)

cases.observation: Edge on the right matches the front-left corner

cases.description:
Definitely an adjacent corner swap because the outermost corner facelets are identical.

Recognizable as Ra-Perm because the edge on the right is the opposite of the front corner and the edge on the left matches the front-right corner.

You might find the "malformed" pair at the front-left is useful during recognition.

feature.description:
The miscellaneous cases with matching bookends can only be a F-Perm, R-Perm or G-Perm.

The checkerboard pattern in the F-Perm (malformed 2x2 block) distinguishes it from the R-Perms and G-Perms (malformed pairs).

F-Perm = 3 colors, R-Perms / G-Perms = 4 colors.
feature.name: Miscellaneous with Bookends

cases.observation: Malformed pair at front-left

cases.description:
Clearly a R-Perm because of the long checkerboard pattern (5 facelets).

Easily recognizable as Ra-Perm because the checkerboard pattern is on the right.

The edge on the left is also the opposite of the rear corner.

feature.description:
Headlights containing an adjacent edge can only be a R-Perm, G-Perm or A-Perm.

The presence of a checkerboard pattern (4 or 5 facelets) is considered to differentiate cases.

R-Perms = 3 colors, A-Perms / G-Perms = 4 colors.
feature.name: Headlights (Adjacent Edge)

cases.observation: Checkerboard pattern on the right (5 facelets)

badmephisto.comment:
Again
for this one I find it easiest to track an F2L pair. Remember the first
part using just notation because it is easy. After R'F you have an F2L
pair on the bottom. Then you do RUR'U' trigger. Next, R'F' reconnects
that F2L pair and aligns it with the whites on top, and R2U' just
finishes it all up.

logiqx.description: Playing with [F2L] pairs - track BR + FL
Contains an 8-move [commutator] - [R' D R, U]

Easily recognizable as Rb-Perm because the checkerboard pattern is on the left.

The edge on the right is also the opposite of the rear corner.

Recognizable as Rb-Perm because the edge on the left is the opposite of the front corner and the edge on the right matches the front-left corner.

You might find the "malformed" pair at the front-right is useful during recognition.

F-Perm = 3 colors, R-Perms / G-Perms = 4 colors.

Definitely an adjacent corner swap because the outermost corner facelets are identical.

Recognizable as Rb-Perm because of the 2-bar at the back-right and the edge on the left matching the front-right corner.

You might find the "malformed" pair at the front-left is useful during recognition.

feature.description:
2-Bar outers connected to an adjacent corner can only be a R-Perm or T-Perm.

The edge adjacent to the 2-bar is considered to differentiate cases.

R-Perms = 3 colors, T-Perm = 4 colors.

cases.description:
Clearly a R-Perm because the headlights contain an adjacent edge color.

Easily recognizable as Rb-Perm because the headlights are on the right and inside 2-bar on the left.

feature.description:
Headlights accompanied by an inside 2-bar can only be a T-Perm or R-Perm.

badmephisto.comment:
I
find it easy to learn this algorithm by tracking F2L pairs around the
cube.RUR'U' takes out a pair. R'F hides it and takes the other pair out
to the top layer. R2U'R' aligns this pair with the whites and hides
that pair. Now all the pairs are hidden from the top layer. Now we do
U' on the Top Layer. Finally RUR'F' takes the second pair out and
aligns it with the whites again, and restores the First Two Layers.

description: The basis of J-Perms and F-Perm.

badmephisto.comment:
Note
how the algorithm is basically always R and then U' U U U' in that
symmetrical order accompanying the R, and lastly R' and fix up rest by
aligning pieces.

description: Mirror of Ub-Perm on the U.

logiqx.description: [MU] [commutator] / [conjugate] - [M2 U: [M, U2]]
[MU] [commutator] / [conjugate] - [M2 U: [M', U2]]
[Conjugate] of [F2L] insert - [R U': R U R U R U' R' U' R' U']
[Conjugate] of [F2L] insert - [R' U: U' R' U' R' U' R U R U R]

name: PLL Ua

cases.description:
Definitely an U-Perm because of the bar and headlights.

Recognizable as Ua-Perm (CCW) because the headlights contain an adjacent edge color.

You may also notice that the edge on the right is the opposite of the bar on the left.

feature.description:
The 3-bar with headlights can only be an U-Perm.

The lone edge is considered to differentiate cases.

U-Perms = 3 colors.
feature.name: 3-Bar with Headlights

cases.observation: Headlights contain an adjacent edge

cases.description:
Clearly an [EPLL] because of the headlights on both sides. Definitely an U-Perm because there are exactly 3 colors.

Recognizable as Ua-Perm (CCW) because the edge on the left matches the headlights on the right.

Alternatively, recognisable because the edge on the right is the opposite of the headlights on the left.

You might find the checkerboard pattern (4 facelets) on the left is useful during recognition.

feature.description:
Double headlights without an opposite edge can only be a Z-Perm or U-Perm.

The two edges are considered to differentiate cases. The Z-Perm is the most distinct.

U-Perms = 3 colors, Z-Perm = 2 or 4 colors.
feature.name: Double Lights (Adjacent Edges)

cases.observation: Left edge matches right headlights

cases.description:
Clearly an [EPLL] because of the headlights on both sides. Definitely an U-Perm because there are exactly 3 colors.

Recognizable as Ua-Perm (CCW) because the headlights on the right contain the opposite edge color.

Another way to recognize as Ua-Perm (CCW) is because the edge on the left matches the headlights on the right.

You might find the checkerboard pattern (4 facelets) on the left useful during recognition.

feature.description:
Double headlights with at least one opposite edge can only be a H-Perm or U-Perm.

The two edges are considered to differentiate cases. The H-Perm is the most distinct.

U-Perms = 3 colors, H-Perm = 4 colors.
feature.name: Double Lights (Opposite Edge)

cases.observation: Right headlights contain the opposite edge

cases.description:
Definitely an U-Perm because of the bar and headlights.

Easily recognizable as Ua-Perm (CCW) because the headlights contain the opposite edge color.

feature.description:
The 3-bar with headlights can only be an U-Perm.

The lone edge is considered to differentiate cases.

U-Perms = 3 colors.
feature.name: 3-Bar with Headlights

cases.observation: Headlights contain the opposite edge

badmephisto.comment:
The
way I remember it: R2 U, then the RUR'U' trigger, then the last two
letters of the RUR'U' trigger, then do R' and fix up rest by aligning
pieces and putting them to their right positions.

description: Mirror of Ua-Perm on the U.

[Conjugate] of [F2L] insert - [R' U: R' U' R' U' R' U R U R U]

Easily recognizable as Ub-Perm (CW) because the headlights contain the opposite edge color.

Recognizable as Ub-Perm (CW) because the headlights on the left contain the opposite edge color.

Another way to recognize as Ub-Perm (CW) is because the edge on the right matches the headlights on the left.

You might find the checkerboard pattern (4 facelets) on the right useful during recognition.

Double headlights with at least one opposite edge can only be a H-Perm or U-Perm.

The two edges are considered to differentiate cases. The H-Perm is the most distinct.

U-Perms = 3 colors, H-Perm = 4 colors.

Clearly an [EPLL] because of the headlights on both sides. Definitely an U-Perm because there are exactly 3 colors.

Recognizable as Ub-Perm (CW) because the edge on the right matches the headlights on the left.

Alternatively, recognisable because the edge on the left is the opposite of the headlights on the right.

You might find the checkerboard pattern (4 facelets) on the right is useful during recognition.

Double headlights without an opposite edge can only be a Z-Perm or U-Perm.

U-Perms = 3 colors, Z-Perm = 2 or 4 colors.

Definitely an U-Perm because of the bar and headlights.

Recognizable as Ub-Perm (CW) because the headlights contain an adjacent edge color.

You may also notice that the edge on the left is the opposite of the bar on the right.

The 3-bar with headlights can only be an U-Perm.

U-Perms = 3 colors.

badmephisto.comment:
I
don't really have a great way to memorize this and thats why I rated
this as a hard algorithm. I kind of just did it until I had it in my
muscle memory. Note how the R'FRF at the end is ALMOST the common
R'FRF' trigger, but with F instead of F' at the end.

logiqx.description: Two-handed algorithm includes a hidden rotation
Extract [F2L] pair (BR), rotate, [AUF], [RFAS], [AUF], [Sexy Move]
Playing with [F2L] pairs - track BR + BL

cases.description:
Definitely a diagonal corner swap because the outermost corner facelets are adjacent colors.

Easily recognizable as V-Perm because of the 2x2 block at the front, bookended by opposite corner colors.

feature.description:
Symmetrical 2-bars and 2x2 blocks can only be a Y-Perm, A-Perm or V-Perm.

The outer corners are considered to differentiate cases. The Y-Perm and V-Perm are most distinctive.

A-Perms = 3 colors, Y-Perm / V-Perm = 4 colors.
feature.name: Double 2-Bar (Symmetric)

cases.observation: Outer corners are the opposites of the block

cases.description:
Definitely a diagonal corner swap because the outermost corner facelets are adjacent colors.

Recognizable as V-Perm because of the 2-bar at the back-left.

You might find the "malformed" pair at the front-right is useful during recognition.

feature.description:
2-Bar outers connected to an opposite corner can only be a V-Perm, G-Perm or A-Perm.

The side adjacent to the 2-bar is considered to differentiate cases.

G-Perms = 3 colors, V-Perms / A-Perms = 4 colors.
feature.name: 2-Bar outer (Opposite Corner)

cases.observation: Almost checkerboard pattern on the right (4 facelets)

cases.description:
Definitely a diagonal corner swap because the outermost corner facelets are adjacent colors.

Recognizable as V-Perm because of the "malformed" 2x2 block at the front, resulting in a checkerboard pattern (4 facelets).

feature.description:
The miscellaneous cases without matching bookends can only be an E-Perm, V-Perm or Y-Perm.

The checkerboard pattern in the V-Perm (malformed 2x2 block) distinguishes it from the E-Perm (malformed pair) and Y-Perm.

E-Perm / V-Perm / Y-Perm = 4 colors.
feature.name: Miscellaneous without Bookends

cases.notes: Learn the features of E and V
cases.observation: Malformed 2x2 block (checkerboard pattern)

cases.description:
Definitely a diagonal corner swap because the outermost corner facelets are adjacent colors.

Recognizable as V-Perm because of the 2-bar at the back-right.

You might find the "malformed" pair at the front-left is useful during recognition.

feature.description:
2-Bar outers connected to an opposite corner can only be a V-Perm, G-Perm or A-Perm.

The side adjacent to the 2-bar is considered to differentiate cases.

G-Perms = 3 colors, V-Perms / A-Perms = 4 colors.
feature.name: 2-Bar outer (Opposite Corner)

cases.observation: Almost checkerboard pattern on the left (4 facelets)

badmephisto.comment:
Again
I find it helpful to see how F2L pairs move around for this algorithm.
F brings an F2L pair to the top, RU'R' inserts that pair back to the
middle. Now again as before, all F2L is again intact, but slightly
messed up. Then U' is done as in T permutation, and then RUR'F' is
AGAIN used to take that pair and insert it back where it was before.
The result will leave you with an OLL, which after when you fix using
the appropriate algorithm, you will be left with Ypermutation at the
end. Note that the OLL is very easy: It takes one pair out to top
layer, and inserts it back a different way (in particular, using R'FRF')

description: Used with no headlights, fairly easy.

logiqx.description: [OLL] combination - [Mounted Fish], [sexy-sledge]
One-handed algorithm is fast despite the re-grips

name: PLL Y

cases.description:
Definitely a diagonal corner swap because the outermost corner facelets are adjacent colors.

Easily recognizable as Y-Perm because the 2-Bar outers are a unique feature.

The corner at the front makes this case very distinctive due to the opposite colors.

feature.description:
Symmetrical 2-bars and 2x2 blocks can only be a Y-Perm, A-Perm or V-Perm.

The outer corners are considered to differentiate cases. The Y-Perm and V-Perm are most distinctive.

A-Perms = 3 colors, Y-Perm / V-Perm = 4 colors.
feature.name: Double 2-Bar (Symmetric)

cases.observation: 2-Bar outers on the left and right

cases.description:
Definitely a diagonal corner swap because the outermost corner facelets are adjacent colors.

Recognizable as Y-Perm because of the 2-bar at the front-left and the edge on the right matching the back-left corner.

feature.description:
Inside 2-bars can only be a G-Perm or Y-Perm.

The edge adjacent to the 2-bar is considered to differentiate cases.

G-Perms / Y-Perm = 4 colors.
feature.name: Inside 2-Bar

cases.observation: Edge on the right matches the back-left corner

cases.description:
Definitely a diagonal corner swap because the outermost corner facelets are adjacent colors.

This is the only angle for a diagonal corner swap without a visible pair, 2x2 block, "malformed" pair or"malformed" 2x2 block.

Most people find the "outer" checkerboard pattern (4 facelets) is useful during recognition.

feature.description:
The miscellaneous cases without matching bookends can only be an E-Perm, V-Perm or Y-Perm.

The checkerboard pattern in the V-Perm (malformed 2x2 block) distinguishes it from the E-Perm (malformed pair) and Y-Perm.

E-Perm / V-Perm / Y-Perm = 4 colors.
feature.name: Miscellaneous without Bookends

cases.notes: Learn the features of E and Y
cases.observation: "Outer" checkerboard pattern (4 facelets)

cases.description:
Definitely a diagonal corner swap because the outermost corner facelets are adjacent colors.

Recognizable as Y-Perm because of the 2-bar at the front-right and the edge on the left matching the back-right corner.

feature.description:
Inside 2-bars can only be a G-Perm or Y-Perm.

The edge adjacent to the 2-bar is considered to differentiate cases.

G-Perms / Y-Perm = 4 colors.
feature.name: Inside 2-Bar

cases.observation: Edge on the left matches the back-right corner

badmephisto.comment: Similar to the H permutation, I find this easy to remember, and I saw some people executing it extremely quickly.

description: Simple to remember, hard to execute.

logiqx.description: Intuitive - Solve UF + UB then solve remaining edges
Intuitive - Solve UL + UR then solve remaining edges
Playing with [F2L] pairs - track BR + FR
Playing with [F2L] pairs - track FR + BR

name: PLL Z

cases.description:
Clearly an [EPLL] because of the headlights on both sides. Exactly 2 colors, unlike U-Perms which have 3 colors.

The edge on the left matches the headlights on the right and the edge on the right matches the headlights on the left.

Easily recognizable as Z-Perm because of the distinctive checkerboard pattern (6 facelets).

The Z-Perm has two appearances and looks the same after a U2.

feature.description:
Double headlights without an opposite edge can only be a Z-Perm or U-Perm.

The two edges are considered to differentiate cases. The Z-Perm is the most distinct.

U-Perms = 3 colors, Z-Perm = 2 or 4 colors.
feature.name: Double Lights (Adjacent Edges)

cases.observation: Distinctive checkerboard pattern (6 facelets)

cases.description:
Clearly an [EPLL] because of the headlights on both sides. Exactly 4 colors, unlike U-Perms which have 3 colors.

The edge on the left is the opposite of the headlights on the right. The edge on the right is the opposite of the headlights on the left.

Recognizable as Z-Perm because both sets of headlights contain an adjacent edge color.

The Z-Perm has two appearances and looks the same after a U2.

feature.description:
Double headlights without an opposite edge can only be a Z-Perm or U-Perm.

The two edges are considered to differentiate cases. The Z-Perm is the most distinct.

U-Perms = 3 colors, Z-Perm = 2 or 4 colors.
feature.name: Double Lights (Adjacent Edges)

cases.observation: Both headlights contain an adjacent edge
